title: Třinec
text:
Třinec (; ; ) is a city in <a href="Fr%C3%BDdek-M%C3%ADstek%20District">Frýdek-Místek District</a> in the <a href="Moravian-Silesian%20Region">Moravian-Silesian Region</a> of the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>. It has about 35,000 inhabitants and is the least populated <a href="Statutory%20city%20%28Czech%20Republic%29">statutory city</a> in the country.
The city is an important cultural centre of the <a href="Polish%20minority%20in%20the%20Czech%20Republic">Polish minority in Zaolzie</a>, which makes up 13.9% of the population (as of 2011).
Třinec is notable for the <a href="T%C5%99inec%20Iron%20and%20Steel%20Works">Třinec Iron and Steel Works</a> steel plant, the largest in the country, which still has a major impact on the city, on its character, demographics, and <a href="air%20quality">air quality</a>.
Administrative parts.
Třinec is made up of thirteen town parts and villages:
Etymology.
The name Třinec is of topographic origin, derived from the Slavic word for <a href="Reed%20%28plant%29">reed</a> (Polish: "trzcina", Czech: "třtina").
Geography.
Třinec is located in the historical region of <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesia">Cieszyn Silesia</a>. It lies on the <a href="Poland">Polish</a> border and also near the <a href="Slovakia">Slovak</a> border, which is about of the city centre. It is situated approximately away from the city of <a href="Ostrava">Ostrava</a> and about from <a href="Prague">Prague</a>.
Třinec lies on the <a href="Olza%20%28river%29">Olza</a> River. The elevation of the built-up area is approximately above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a>. The southern, sparsely populated part of the municipal territory is located in the <a href="Moravian-Silesian%20Beskids">Moravian-Silesian Beskids</a> mountain range and the eponymous protected landscape area. The municipal border runs along the peaks of several mountains, including Ostrý (which is, with an elevation of , the highest point in Třinec), Smrčina, at , Šindelná, at , and Javorový, at .
Climate.
Třinec has a <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental climate</a> ("Cfb" in the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>).
History.
The first written mention of Třinec is from 1444, but the village was probably founded already in the second half of the 14th century. Politically, the village then belonged to the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Teschen">Duchy of Teschen</a>, a <a href="Fee%20%28feudal%20tenure%29">fee</a> of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Kingdom of Bohemia</a>, which after 1526 became part of the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>. In 1770, the village had about 200 inhabitants and was completely agricultural.
The area was rich in <a href="iron%20ore">iron ore</a> deposits and had sufficient water energy and a high supply of wood, which were the main reasons to establish an <a href="iron%20works">iron works</a> there. The iron mill began operation in 1839, becoming the largest in the entire <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesia">Cieszyn Silesia</a>, and became a major milestone in the history of the village, which reoriented itself to industry. After the construction of the <a href="Ko%C5%A1ice%E2%80%93Bohum%C3%ADn%20Railway">Košice–Bohumín Railway</a> line in 1871, rapid development of the town took place.
After the <a href="revolutions%20of%201848%20in%20the%20Austrian%20Empire">revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire</a>, a modern <a href="municipality">municipal division</a> was introduced in the re-established <a href="Austrian%20Silesia">Austrian Silesia</a>. The village as a municipality was added to the <a href="Districts%20of%20Austria">political</a> and <a href="legal%20district">legal district</a> of <a href="Cieszyn">Cieszyn</a>. According to censuses conducted in 1880–1910, the population of the municipality grew from 1,792 in 1880 to 3,849 in 1910, with a majority being native Polish speakers (growing from 51.4% in 1880 to 96.6% in 1900 and 96% in 1910), accompanied by a German-speaking minority (at most 32.5% in 1880, then dropping to 12.2% in 1900, and up to 24.3% in 1910) and Czech speakers (peaking in 1890 at 17.4%, then dropping to 6.7% in 1910). In terms of religion, in 1910 the majority were <a href="Roman%20Catholics">Roman Catholics</a> (63.2%), followed by <a href="Protestants">Protestants</a> (34.5%), and <a href="Jews">Jews</a> (1.9%). The village was also traditionally inhabited by <a href="Cieszyn%20Vlachs">Cieszyn Vlachs</a>, speaking the <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesian%20dialect">Cieszyn Silesian dialect</a>.
After <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the fall of <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Czechoslovak%20War">Polish–Czechoslovak War</a>, and the division of <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesia">Cieszyn Silesia</a> in 1920, it became a part of <a href="Czechoslovak%20Republic%20%281918-1938%29">Czechoslovakia</a>. In 1931, Třinec was promoted to a town.
Following the <a href="Munich%20Agreement">Munich Agreement</a> in October 1938, together with the <a href="Zaolzie">Zaolzie</a> region, it was annexed by <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">Poland</a>, administratively adjoined to <a href="Cieszyn%20County">Cieszyn County</a> of the <a href="Silesian%20Voivodeship%20%281920%E2%80%9339%29">Silesian Voivodeship</a>. It was then annexed by <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> at the beginning of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. After the war, it was restored to <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>.
In 1946, the villages of <a href="Ly%C5%BEbice">Lyžbice</a>, <a href="Doln%C3%AD%20L%C3%AD%C5%A1tn%C3%A1">Dolní Líštná</a>, and <a href="Konsk%C3%A1%20%28T%C5%99inec%29">Konská</a> were joined to Třinec. In 1956–1977, a large housing estate was built in Lyžbice, and it became the most populated town part of Třinec. Afterwards, Lyžbice became a new <a href="downtown">downtown</a>, taking the place of <a href="Star%C3%A9%20M%C4%9Bsto%20%28T%C5%99inec%29">Staré Město</a> (lit. "old town").
The municipalities of <a href="Guty%20%28T%C5%99inec%29">Guty</a>, <a href="Karpentn%C3%A1">Karpentná</a>, <a href="Nebory">Nebory</a>, <a href="Old%C5%99ichovice%20%28T%C5%99inec%29">Oldřichovice</a>, <a href="Ropice">Ropice</a>, <a href="Tyra%20%28T%C5%99inec%29">Tyra</a>, and <a href="Vendryn%C4%9B">Vendryně</a> were joined to Třinec in 1980. However, Vendryně became an independent municipality in 1995 and Ropice followed in 2000. In 2018, Třinec became a <a href="Statutory%20city%20%28Czech%20Republic%29">statutory city</a>.
Economy.
The <a href="T%C5%99inec%20Iron%20and%20Steel%20Works">Třinec Iron and Steel Works</a> company is one of the largest employers in the Czech Republic. Including smaller production plants outside Třinec, the company employ 7,000 people (as of 2021).
Culture.
The year's biggest event is the "Hutnický den" ("Metallurgy Day"), which features numerous live performances from bands and artists from all over the country and abroad. It takes place every year in May, but was not held in 2020 and 2021.
From 1993 to 2012, one of the oldest and most famous rock festivals in the Czech Republic, "Noc plná hvězd" ("star-studded night"), was held here every year.
Sport.
The city is represented by the successful <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> team <a href="HC%20Ocel%C3%A1%C5%99i%20T%C5%99inec">HC Oceláři Třinec</a>, which has been playing in the <a href="Czech%20Extraliga">Czech Extraliga</a> since 1995 and has won several times.
Oceláři (Steelers) play their home games at <a href="Werk%20Arena">Werk Arena</a>, which opened in 2014 and has a seating capacity of 5,200. The arena also hosted the <a href="Czech%20Republic%20Davis%20Cup%20team">Team Czech Republic</a> at the <a href="2016%20Davis%20Cup%20World%20Group">2016 Davis Cup World Group</a>.
The city's <a href="Association%20football">football</a> team, <a href="FK%20Fotbal%20T%C5%99inec">FK Fotbal Třinec</a>, plays in the <a href="Czech%20National%20Football%20League">Czech National Football League</a> (second tier of the Czech football system).
Třinec also has an <a href="Track%20and%20field%20athletics">athletics</a> club, founded in 1951. Sports that have a tradition in Třinec include orienteering, weightlifting, Greco-Roman wrestling, road cycling, and chess.
Sights.
Třinec is poor in monuments. The main historic landmark is the Church of Saint Albert, built in the 1880s.
A notable building is the wooden Church of Corpus Cristi in Guty. The original church from the 16th century was destroyed by a <a href="Arson">deliberate fire</a> in 2017. In 2021, a replica was completed on its site.
In 1969, Třinec Iron and Steel Works opened a company museum, which has been jointly operated with the city as the museum of both the company and the city since 1992.
Twin towns – sister cities.
Třinec is <a href="Sister%20city">twinned</a> with:
